title: Charging by friction - Object X -5 nC and Object Y

content.question: Two spheres, Sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, are made of different materials. They are each electrically neutral and are electrically isolated from other objects. They are rubbed together, after which Sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> has a net charge of <math alttext="negative 5 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>. Which of the following claims is correct about the charge of Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>?

choices.label: Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> gains protons, resulting in a positive net charge.
Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> loses protons, resulting in a negative net charge.
Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> gains electrons, resulting in a negative net charge.
Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> loses electrons, resulting in a positive net charge.

content.answer: Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> loses electrons, resulting in a positive net charge.

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

topic.text: 8.2: Conservation of Electric Charge and the Process of Charging

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
